comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Brilliant photo of the ORIENT. So often she is in the background, not featured. This is the ship which got me sucked into these old photos, due to a famous painting by Charles Conder The Departure of the Orient - Circular Quay (1888) (AGNSW), now available in the amazing GoogleArtProject - www.googleartproject.com/collection/art-gallery-of-new-so... - press the little man for 'Museum View' to visit the painting at the AGNSW.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
32162360@N00
comment._content:
Particularly as the next photo shows Admiralty House before the additional floor was added in 1885.

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons/8725149186/in/photostream]

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Amazing! Have been playing around with GoogleArt, how clever! 1884 seems logical re the dates of the other images in the album & the smaller craft & spectators would certainly indicate a big regatta...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Description of the 1884 Anniversary Regatta in the SMH 28/1/1884 p.8, including this -
" ... In this instance, the flagship was the Orient, one of the largest and best finished steamers afloat. She was surrounded by craft of all kinds and dimensions, and so numerous that but for the skilful manner in which they were directed they must, as they flitted or darted to and fro, have met with accidents. They gave the harbour in the vicinity of Farm Cove an appearance the animation of which was heightened by the crowds of persons who congregated at Fort Macquarie and Mrs. Macquarie's Chair, and by the fluttering flags of the vessels at Circular Quay, amongst which was the gay tri-colours hoisted as a compliment to the colony by a Messageries Maritimes steamers. The decks of the Orient made most agreeable promenades, and were occupied by several hundreds of persons, including a very large proportion of ladies, who in the natural pride of their sex displayed the magnificent costumes of the present period. On one deck was stationed the band of the Naval Volunteers and on another that of the Vernon, so that visitors had a plentitude of music in addition to their other enjoyments, some of which appeared to closely partake of the character of flirtation. ..."
trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13550521

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Oh no they didn't! Flirtatious behaviour, deary me. I rather like the description of the flagships as indicators of the colony's progress, quite evocative.
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/anmm_thecommons] I just discovered that the Admiralty House second floor (see notes) was added in 1891-2,  not 1885 (Wikipedia article is misleading).  This might throw out the dating of these ORIENT photos - as far as I can tell, the ORIENT was the flagship at the 1884 Anniversary Regatta only.

comment.author: 33147718@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Hmm well ORIENT doesn't have as many flags as she might if a flagship. But some event is going on, with all the spectators & busy harbour...
comment.authorname: Australian National Maritime Museum on The Commons
